liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Samah Sabawi, a Palestinian Australian playwright and author has revealed what life is like for those in Gaza, with family members and friends struggling in the face of Israel retaliation. "It's a very dire situation," She told News Channel's Ros Childs. "They are under siege, under Israeli occupation. They're literally in an Israeli cage and Israel is harming them yet again." She felt like the world, including Australia, was treating Palestinian life as totally worthless and people in Gaza were living in fear not knowing when bombardments would happen. "This is the first time Israel is going into a bombardment campaign having already taken the green light from governments like the Australian Government and the United States and other world governments," she said. "They got the green light to go in and commit the war crimes. That can I do whatever they want and I think this is the lowest point in the Australian history where it comes to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict." She also said she was now worried about losing contact with those inside Gaza. "Everything is cut off," she said. "I know the hospitals are struggling, saying they are unable to deal with especially the casualties. The death rate is shooting through the roof. A lot of families have been wiped out in the last 48 hours." Watch the video below as Australians share stories of what their families are experiencing in Israel and Gaza.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian Australian describes 'dire situation'

children.content: Samah Sabawi.
(ABC News)
Samah Sabawi
, a Palestinian Australian playwright and author has revealed what life is like for those in Gaza, with family members and friends struggling in the face of Israel retaliation.
"It's a very dire situation," She told News Channel's Ros Childs.
"They are under siege, under Israeli occupation. They're literally in an Israeli cage and Israel is harming them yet again."
She felt like the world, including Australia, was treating Palestinian life as totally worthless and people in Gaza were living in fear not knowing when bombardments would happen.

"This is the first time Israel is going into a bombardment campaign having already taken the green light from governments like the Australian Government and the United States and other world governments," she said.

"They got the green light to go in and commit the war crimes. That can I do whatever they want and I think this is the lowest point in the Australian history where it comes to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict."
She also said she was now worried about losing contact with those inside Gaza.
"Everything is cut off," she said.

"I know the hospitals are struggling, saying they are unable to deal with especially the casualties. The death rate is shooting through the roof. A lot of families have been wiped out in the last 48 hours."
Watch the video below as Australians share stories of what their families are experiencing in Israel and Gaza.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Reserve Brigadier General Amir Avivi told 7.30 Hamas would want to keep hostages alive "for later negotiations". "[The] issue of hostages is something that usually on an everyday basis we talk about, but now this is prisoners of war. […] And we're in a war which we need to first and foremost win," he told 7.30's Sarah Ferguson. He said Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has "no other choice" but to proceed with a full scale assault, even if it means that hostages are killed. Avivi said he believed there was a lack of intelligence from Israeli forces before the Hamas attack. “The Gaza division was especially talking about the fact that it was a holiday and Saturday was really conducting itself normally, many people were on vacation,” he said. “The extent of that attack was so big and simultaneous that the soldiers themselves found themselves fighting their first fight and not really being able at the same time to assist in towns and towns found themselves without army assistance for a long time, and this was devastating.” Reporting by ABC 7.30
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It's in Hamas's interest to keep hostages alive, Israeli Reserve Brigadier says

mediaThumbnail.caption:
Reserve Brigadier-General Amir Avivi was the deputy commander of the Israeli Defence Force's Gaza Division.

Like many, he compared the shock failure to predict this attack by the terrorist group Hamas to the 1973 war of Yom Kippur when a coalition of Arab states launched a surprise attack on a Jewish holiday. He spoke to Sarah Ferguson.

children.content: Sarah Ferguson

children.content: Israeli Reserve Brigadier General Amir Avivi told 7.30 Hamas would want to keep hostages alive "for later negotiations".

"[The] issue of hostages is something that usually on an everyday basis we talk about, but now this is prisoners of war. […] And we're in a war which we need to first and foremost win," he told 7.30's Sarah Ferguson.
He said Israel's Prime Minister
Benjamin Netanyahu
has "no other choice" but to proceed with a full scale assault, even if it means that hostages are killed.
Avivi said he believed there was a lack of intelligence from Israeli forces before the Hamas attack.
“The Gaza division was especially talking about the fact that it was a holiday and Saturday was really conducting itself normally, many people were on vacation,” he said.

“The extent of that attack was so big and simultaneous that the soldiers themselves found themselves fighting their first fight and not really being able at the same time to assist in towns and towns found themselves without army assistance for a long time, and this was devastating.”
Reporting by ABC 7.30

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A report from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says more than 187,500 people have been displaced in Gaza. UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, is hosting more than 137,000 people in schools across the territory. The report says air strikes have razed 790 housing units and severely damaged 5,330 in the territory of 2.3 million people. OCHA said damage to water, sanitation and hygiene facilities in Gaza has disrupted service for more than 400,000 people.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says number of people displaced in Gaza has surpassed 187,000

children.content: Palestinians inspect the rubble of the Yassin Mosque destroyed after it was hit by an Israeli airstrike at Shati refugee camp in Gaza City.
(AP Photo: Adel Hana)
A report from the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs says more than 187,500 people have been displaced in Gaza.
UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, is hosting more than 137,000 people in schools across the territory.
The report says air strikes have razed 790 housing units and severely damaged 5,330 in the territory of 2.3 million people.
OCHA said damage to water, sanitation and hygiene facilities in Gaza has disrupted service for more than 400,000 people.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: With just days before the country heads to the polls, there are reports of increasingly hostile behaviour towards staff manning the polling booths, along with allegations of improper conduct by campaigners. The Australian Electoral Commissioner is urging civility at polling booths, amid allegations of increasingly hostile behaviour towards electoral staff. "It's important to contextualise. The behaviour of the vast, vast majority of voters and campaigners from all sides has been perfect. No issues," AEC Commissioner Tom Rodgers told RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas this morning. " It is always a small number of people. I think, particularly a referendum, unleashes passions that can boil over. "We've seen, what I would call, unacceptable conduct including filming of our staff who are just trying to do the right thing. "We, as we have always done, are urging civility by everybody. "The good thing is, that's mostly what we're seeing. I'm encouraging even more of it." You can listen to the full interview from RN Breakfast using the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Unacceptable conduct': AEC urges civility at polling booths

featuredLink.title: 'Unacceptable conduct': AEC urges civility at polling booths - ABC listen

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Local community leaders are assembling in Brisbane this morning to show their support for the Voice to Parliament. Former federal senator and athlete, Nova Peris, and four-time Broncos premiership winner, Steve Renouf, are among those in attendance. They’re joined by Lowitja Institute chairperson Selwyn Button, Nathan Appo from the Institute of Urban Indigenous Health, and CEO of Reconciliation Queensland, Erin Lang .

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tahnee Jash and Marty Smiley Yesterday, young voters arrived at Sydney TAFE’s pre-polling centre to cast their ballot in the first referendum in 24 years. Campaigners outside told us that some voters were unsure about their choice while others walked in with a clear decision in mind. Voters and campaigners alike said finding accurate information wasn't easy and misinformation and disinformation was visible on social media platforms. So, we asked a few young voters about their choice and how they arrived at their decision: Max, electrician apprentice "I voted 'no'. I've heard so many things and apparently, it's going to divide the country," he said. Max says among his friends who are Indigenous, their views on the referendum are split. "A lot of them have said 'no' but I've also got others that said 'yes'," he said. Not knowing a lot about it, I'm just going to stay out of it and vote 'no'." Laila, UTS student "I'm going to vote 'yes'. I feel like we got a lot of information, some of it false, some of it true," she said. Laila says before the referendum, she assumed First Nations people already had a voice on matters that impacted them. "It's just about giving everyone a chance to have their say in a country that is more rightfully theirs, than ours anyway," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yes and No early voters in Sydney's centre

children.content: Reporting by Tahnee Jash and Marty Smiley
Yesterday, young voters arrived at Sydney TAFE’s pre-polling centre to cast their ballot in the first referendum in 24 years.
Campaigners outside told us that some voters were unsure about their choice while others walked in with a clear decision in mind.
Voters and campaigners alike said finding accurate information wasn't easy and misinformation and disinformation was visible on social media platforms.
So, we asked a few young voters about their choice and how they arrived at their decision:
Max, electrician apprentice
Max voted no in the Voice to Parliament referendum.
(ABC News: Marty Smiley)
"I voted 'no'. I've heard so many things and apparently, it's going to divide the country," he said.
Max says among his friends who are Indigenous, their views on the referendum are split.
"A lot of them have said 'no' but I've also got others that said 'yes'," he said.
Not knowing a lot about it, I'm just going to stay out of it and vote 'no'."
Laila, UTS student
Laila voted Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum.
(ABC News: Marty Smiley)
"I'm going to vote 'yes'. I feel like we got a lot of information, some of it false, some of it true," she said.
Laila says before the referendum, she assumed First Nations people already had a voice on matters that impacted them.
"It's just about giving everyone a chance to have their say in a country that is more rightfully theirs, than ours anyway," she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Continuing our series looking at some of the key names in this year's draft, it's time to head west with a look at Dan Curtin. His has been a name that has floated around heavily as the assumption has been West Coast will be desperate to land him, and could facilitate a pick-one trade as a result. While this is largely based on the fact he is from WA, it's also true that he is one of the brightest prospects in the draft. Curtin is a versatile player, tall enough to play as a key-position player and slick enough to move into the midfield, as he did often this year. His left foot is deadly, and he has the rare ability to slow play down around him when he is in possession. My question around Curtin is what position he ends up playing. I'm not sold that he will be a centre-half-back in the AFL, as I don't think he is quite strong enough in the air. His ability at ground-level and skills mean a midfield move is possible, but there just isn't enough exposed form there to be certain he will make it in that spot in the big leagues. But the worst case scenario in Curtin's case is he becomes a dangerous rebounding defender, who can pick teams apart with by foot and play on both tall and small forwards. There is scope for him to become a Jordan Dawson-esque midfielder though, with the leadership attributes to match. He is incredibly professional, and has all the attributes of a 200+ game AFL footballer. He'll more than likely go in the top five, and could well line up in round one for whoever picks him up. Sounds pretty damn good, hey?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Daniel Curtin

children.content: (Getty Images)
Continuing our series looking at some of the key names in this year's draft, it's time to head west with a look at Dan Curtin.

His has been a name that has floated around heavily as the assumption has been West Coast will be desperate to land him, and could facilitate a pick-one trade as a result. While this is largely based on the fact he is from WA, it's also true that he is one of the brightest prospects in the draft.

Curtin is a versatile player, tall enough to play as a key-position player and slick enough to move into the midfield, as he did often this year. His left foot is deadly, and he has the rare ability to slow play down around him when he is in possession.

My question around Curtin is what position he ends up playing. I'm not sold that he will be a centre-half-back in the AFL, as I don't think he is quite strong enough in the air. His ability at ground-level and skills mean a midfield move is possible, but there just isn't enough exposed form there to be certain he will make it in that spot in the big leagues.
(Getty Images)

But the worst case scenario in Curtin's case is he becomes a dangerous rebounding defender, who can pick teams apart with by foot and play on both tall and small forwards. There is scope for him to become a Jordan Dawson-esque midfielder though, with the leadership attributes to match.

He is incredibly professional, and has all the attributes of a 200+ game AFL footballer. He'll more than likely go in the top five, and could well line up in round one for whoever picks him up. Sounds pretty damn good, hey?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Peter Bell spoke to 6PR in Perth last night, and said while he understood the reasons behind Lachie Schultz's trade request, he could not guarantee a trade would be struck. "We're aware of some circumstances – as we are with all our players in the background – I guess some circumstances have arisen where Lachie is keen to explore a return home to Victoria. "Through those discussions we have reminded Lachie – while we understand those circumstances – the fact that he is a contracted player, a much-loved player and a valued player — may mean that there's every possibility that he plays for us next year and sees out his contract at least." Freo are going to want a first round pick at least for Schultz, and are also trying to hit up St Kilda for an early second-rounder for Liam Henry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Freo happy to keep Schultz if deal can't be done

children.content: (Getty Images)
Peter Bell spoke to 6PR in Perth last night, and said while he understood the reasons behind Lachie Schultz's trade request, he could not guarantee a trade would be struck.
"We're aware of some circumstances – as we are with all our players in the background – I guess some circumstances have arisen where Lachie is keen to explore a return home to Victoria.

"Through those discussions we have reminded Lachie – while we understand those circumstances – the fact that he is a contracted player, a much-loved player and a valued player — may mean that there's every possibility that he plays for us next year and sees out his contract at least."
Freo are going to want a first round pick at least for Schultz, and are also trying to hit up St Kilda for an early second-rounder for Liam Henry.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's official — Ben McKay is heading to Essendon, and the AFL is awarding North Melbourne pick three as compensation. SEN and AFL.com.au have reported the news and the AFL is expected to confirm it shortly. That gives North Melbourne picks 2, 3, 15, 21, 44, 56 and 64. Plus two extra late first round picks next year that the AFL has effectively encouraged them to trade this year. It's quite an incredible position to be in.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ben McKay compensation is officially pick three

children.content: (Getty Images)
It's official — Ben McKay is heading to Essendon, and the AFL is awarding North Melbourne pick three as compensation.
SEN and AFL.com.au have reported the news and the AFL is expected to confirm it shortly.
That gives North Melbourne picks 2, 3, 15, 21, 44, 56 and 64. Plus two extra late first round picks next year that the AFL has effectively encouraged them to trade this year.
It's quite an incredible position to be in.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A former chief executive officer with stockbroking firm BBY has appeared in court, charged with fraud. The Australian Securities and Investments Commission alleges that Arunesh Maharaj (aided and abetted by another former BBY employee) obtained a financial advantage for BBY from St George Bank (a division of Westpac). ASIC says it involved obtaining additional funding by improperly drawing down on an overdraft facility which BBY was not entitled between June 2013 and early 2015. BBY was placed into liquidation on 22 June 2015, with significant client shortfalls. Mr Maharaj has been charged with two counts, with each offence carrying a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment. The matter was adjourned until 5 December 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former CEO charged with fraud

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 and broader All Ordinaries have risen for the fourth straight session. Both indices are up around 1.2% (at 1PM AEDT). There is strength in energy and mining stocks, as oil prices increase amid violent clashes in Israel and Palestine. All 11 sectors are higher today, led by utilities (at 3.8%), academic and educational services (3.3%) and technology (2.1%). The top performing stocks are Chalice Mining (+11.3%) and Core Lithium (+9.6%). Top performers: Chalice Mining (+11.3%) Core Lithium (+9.6%) Weebit Nano (+6%) Sayona Mining (6%) Pilbara Minerals (+5.4%) Bottom movers: Neuren Pharmaceuticals (-3%) Computershare (-1%) Newcrest Mining (-1%) Sims (-0.5%) CSR (-0.4%)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, business conditions were down slightly in September, according to the NAB monthly business survey. It fell 3 points to +11 index points, where it's been since May. However, it remains at above average levels. Business confidence was steady (at +1pts) and while sitting below average, has been broadly neutral for several months (suggesting firms are less concerned about the outlook than previously). The survey found cost pressures are easing for business. "The survey showed some positive signs for inflation with cost pressures and price growth easing in the month," said NAB chief economist Alan Oster. "Minimum wage impacts and movements in oil prices have caused some volatility in cost pressures recently but the September survey results suggest the easing trend seen earlier in the year may continue." He says overall the survey points to ongoing resilience in the economy .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What about business confidence?

children.content: Well,
business conditions were down slightly in September,
according to the NAB monthly business survey.
It fell 3 points to +11 index points, where it's been since May.
However, it remains at above average levels.
Business confidence was steady
(at +1pts) and while sitting below average, has been broadly neutral for several months (suggesting firms are less concerned about the outlook than previously).
The survey found cost pressures are easing for business.
"The survey showed some positive signs for inflation with cost pressures and price growth easing in the month," said NAB chief economist Alan Oster.

"Minimum wage impacts and movements in oil prices have caused some volatility in cost pressures recently but the September survey results suggest the easing trend seen earlier in the year may continue."
He says overall the survey points to
ongoing resilience in the economy

image.altText: Michael takes a selfie standing next to his wife

items.synopsis: After 15 years of infertility treatment, Michael Hughes and his wife were left childless and grieving. But since then, they have found healing.

title.children: 'I can't do this anymore': Your stories of being childless not by choice

image.altText: A young woman is on the shoulders of a man in a march. She's holding an Aboriginal flag

items.synopsis: For years, political parties from across the divide have failed equally at bettering the lot of people in the Northern Territory. How will the NT ever see substantive change?

title.children: A 'failed state' or a 'political football'? Australia must face up to the reality of the Northern Territory

image.altText: Composite image of Natasha Wanganeen and James Stevens

items.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price was not on ABC's Q+A but a colleague's defence of her comments on colonisation drew a heated response as the Voice referendum looms large.

title.children: 'Disgusting language': Heated clash over colonisation and Jacinta Price dominates Q+A

image.altText: A close shot of Wong, wearing glasses and speaking, inside parliament house.

items.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong says Israel has a right to defend itself, and judging its security decisions from a distance is "very difficult", as Israel's government vows to cut off food and water to the blockaded Gaza Strip.

title.children: Foreign minister says 'very difficult' to judge from afar, as Israel vows to cut off food and water to Gaza

image.altText: RFK Jr is pictured between two American flags. He looks at the camera and smiles

items.synopsis: Robert F Kennedy Jr abandons the party of his family dynasty and his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, announcing he's running for election as an independent — a possible boost for Donald Trump.

title.children: 'His candidacy is an embarrassment': The Kennedy blowing up Camelot

image.altText: 'I'm voting Yes' pamphlets are held in a hand on a street.

items.synopsis: Tasmania's Liberal premier is urging a Yes vote in Saturday's referendum but the dominant Indigenous group says No. What is happening on the island state and why do polls say it is the only state tracking in favour?

title.children: Why is Tasmania the only state leaning towards a Yes vote in the referendum?

image.altText: Early black and white photo of Manchester band Oasis

items.synopsis: They were one of the biggest bands of the 90s, ended by a bitter sibling rivalry. But almost three decades on, Noel Gallagher says the glory days of Oasis were everything he had hoped they would ever be.

title.children: 'Happy, hedonistic, carefree times': Noel Gallagher on the glory days of Oasis and the feud that ended the band

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit with glasses and slicked-back hair stands in front of the red tail of a Qantas plane.

items.synopsis: Qantas may well be an extreme example of the greed and hubris that is endemic in the corporate world, but it is far from alone, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: The Qantas flame-out is a symptom of something much more serious

image.altText: A dark-haired woman in a grey singlet sleeps in a bed.

items.synopsis: Live streaming has become a multi-billion-dollar industry, as people pay to watch everything from someone sleeping to them eating chips. So what's the appeal?

title.children: Would you pay to wake someone up again and again? Welcome to the world of sleep-fluencers

image.altText: Rockets in the sky over the city of Ashkelon.

items.synopsis: Israel's Iron Dome air defence system is reputed to be the most sophisticated in the world, but experts say it became overwhelmed during Hamas's unprecedented assault. Did it fail and what more can it withstand?

title.children: Israel's Iron Dome was 'overwhelmed' in the Hamas attack. What happens if Hezbollah gets involved?

image.altText: A black and white photograph of a man with square framed glasses and short grey hair.

items.synopsis: David Richards must not have contact with female patients or work outside the Gold Coast where clinic he is based, under conditions imposed by the Health Ombudsman.

title.children: Gold Coast doctor banned from contact with female patients

image.altText: Falcon with feathers poking out of it sits on the edge of a high-rise building ledge.

items.synopsis: The falcons have been laying eggs on the top of the 34-storey building since 1991, but this year, there won't be hatchlings.

title.children: Unhappy ending to breeding season for Melbourne's famous high-rise falcon family
